title: SB 1.18.38-41 | HH Stoka Krishna Swami | 24-04-2023 | Daily Evening Bhagavatam Discourse
speaker: HH Stoka Krishna Swami

segments.key_quote: So this was completely impudent on his part to have cursed the king like that.
segments.summary: The speaker narrates the story of Sringi cursing King Pariksit and his subsequent regret, highlighting the impudence of the act and the realization of the mistake.

segments.key_quote: Hearing his son crying, gradually opened his eyes and saw the dead snake around his neck.
segments.summary: The speaker describes Shamika Rishi's reaction to his son's crying, explaining how he gradually came out of his trance and noticed the dead snake around his neck.

segments.key_quote: Actually, there was nothing seriously wrong in Maharaj Pariksit's act. But the foolish son took it very seriously. And being influenced by Kali, he cursed the king.
segments.summary: The speaker explains that Shamika Rishi did not take the snake incident seriously and attributes Sringi's curse to the influence of Kali, leading to the downfall of Brahmanical power and societal degradation.

segments.key_quote: always the punishment for a mistake should be in proportion to the degree of the mistake that is committed.
segments.summary: The speaker emphasizes the importance of proportionate punishment, highlighting that the curse on King Pariksit was a severe punishment for a minor offense.

segments.key_quote: The king is the best of all human beings. He is the representative of God and he is never to be condemned for any of his actions.
segments.summary: The speaker elaborates on the Vedic concept of the king as a representative of God, emphasizing that a righteous king should not be condemned for his actions and is trained to be a Rajarishi.

segments.key_quote: even if there is something wrong with the king, he is never to be condemned.
segments.summary: The speaker continues to discuss the role of the king, explaining that even if a king makes a mistake, he should not be condemned, and reiterates that the punishment should be proportionate to the offense.
